title: 113_hr3628
content:
The "Transportation Reports Elimination Act of 2014" eliminates certain reporting requirements. The "Transportation Reports Elimination Act of 2014" removes reporting requirements related to air traffic services, annual financial summaries, pipeline safety grants, and innovative financing of air traffic control equipment. The Century of Aviation Reauthorization Act is amended to remove certain subsections and repeal the justification for air defense identification zone. Additionally, standards for aircraft noise reduction and environmental reports are also amended. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to remove and redesignate certain paragraphs. The Indian Environmental General Assistance Program Act of 1992 is amended by striking a subsection. The Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 is amended to strike and redesignate subsections. SEC. 3. Consolidation or modification of certain reports. Marine Safety Report to Congress is amended to include details on civilian and military Coast Guard personnel assigned to marine safety positions and identify understaffed positions. Conforming amendments are made to Section 57 of title 14, United States Code. The Maritime Transportation Security Annual Report is amended to include an annual report submission requirement by the Secretary of the department where the Coast Guard operates to specific congressional committees. The report must contain a summary of security standards established in the preceding fiscal year. The Maritime Transportation Security Annual Report must include details on security standards compliance by ports, terminals, vessel operators, and shippers. It should also provide information on the number of security zones for vessels with hazardous cargo and the vessels provided with security escorts. The Maritime Transportation Security Annual Report must include compliance details for security standards by ports, terminals, vessel operators, and shippers. It should also cover the number of security zones for vessels carrying hazardous cargo and the resources needed for waterborne escorts for such cargo. Amendments define especially hazardous cargo as specific substances like anhydrous ammonia and chlorine. The Secretary determines regulations for hazardous cargo transportation in maritime commerce. Amendments are made to vessel and intermodal security reports under the Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Act of 2004. Infrastructure investment needs report in title 23, United States Code, is also amended. Amendments are made to various sections of title 23 and title 49 of the United States Code, changing reporting deadlines and requirements for transportation safety evaluations. Amendments to MAP-21 include changes to reporting deadlines and requirements for transportation safety evaluations, such as expanding briefings to include the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives. SEC. 4. PAPERLESS REPORTS. (a) Amendment to Section 130(g) of title 23, United States Code requires the Secretary to publish a biennial report on state progress in improving railway-highway crossings on the Department of Transportation website.
(b) Amendment to Section 144(d)(1)(B) of title 23, United States Code mandates the public availability of the National Bridge and Tunnel Inventory Report on the Department of Transportation website. Section 327 of title 23, United States Code is amended to require the Secretary to publish an annual report on the administration of the program on the Department of Transportation website. Additionally, Section 402(n) is amended to make the Highway Safety Programs Biennial Report available to the public on the Department of Transportation website. (e) In-Vehicle Alcohol Detection Device Research Reports.--Section 403(h)(4) of title 23, United States Code, is amended to require the annual report to be made available to the public on the Department of Transportation website.
(f) National ITS Program Plan Reporting.--Section 512(b) of title 23, United States Code, is amended to mandate the biennial publication and updating of the report on the Department of Transportation website.
(g) Advisory Committee Report.--Section 515(h)(4) of title 23, United States Code, is amended to specify changes regarding the Advisory Committee report. The United States Code is amended to update reporting requirements, including making reports available on the Department of Transportation website. Amendments include changing reporting frequency to biennially and specifying public availability of modified reports. The United States Code is amended to update reporting requirements, including making reports available on the Department of Transportation website. Amendments include changing reporting frequency to biennially and specifying public availability of modified reports to the public. The United States Code is amended to update reporting requirements, including making reports available on the Department of Transportation website. Reports will now be available biennially to the public on the Department's website.
